Situation1: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: I glanced at the rearview mirror, catching the relaxed smile of my passenger. He was in no rush, chatting about his upcoming lunch with friends. The city traffic was light, and I felt at ease, focused on getting him there safely and on time, just as any good taxi driver should. Then, at a red light, I noticed a man stumbling on the sidewalk, clearly drunk and struggling to stay upright. He looked lost, maybe even in danger of wandering into the street. My Christian conscience screamed at me to help, to show compassion and not just drive by. But as a taxi driver, I had a responsibility to my passenger—he expected a smooth, uninterrupted ride, not an unexpected detour. My hands tightened on the wheel. Should I stop and risk inconveniencing my passenger, or keep driving and ignore the man in need? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something different, and I felt torn, caught in the tension between duty and faith.
